question: What is Residual Cash Earnings (RCE)?
answer: Residual Cash Earnings or “RCE” is a simple and comprehensive measure that will provide better insights into where value is being created or destroyed as it “dollarizes” into one metric the trade-offs between growth, returns and cash flow. RCE tells you whether the value of your outputs exceed the value of your inputs and compares that value creation to what you could have generated had you invested in another alternative. RCE is a cash-based measure of economic profit where “up is good”, and “down is bad.” Improving RCE is what matters most! We believe this measure will be fundamental in our drive to increase top line growth through innovation, improve margins, and deleverage through better working capital and cash management.

question: How do I calculate RCE?
answer:
We start with the familiar measure EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest Tax Depreciation and Amortization), add back R&D, and then subtract taxes, which give us “Gross Cash Earnings” (GCE, which is a measure of “profit”).
We then compare this to the capital charge, which represents the required return (or GCE or “profit”) investors expect to achieve given the amount they have invested in the business. The capital charge is investors’ required return of 8.5% multiplied by the Gross Operating Assets (GOA). GOA consists of the operating assets of the business (i.e., Net Working Capital, Gross Property Plant and Equipment, Capitalized R&D). Since we don’t expense R&D, we capitalize 8 years of R&D expense and treat it as an investment. This encourages management to invest in growth but at the same time holds management accountable for generating a return on the R&D that has been invested. 
Finally, subtracting the capital charge from GCE gives us RCE, as shown below, which tells you how much GCE or “profit” you generated relative to the amount of GCE or “profit” investors expected given the amount of GOA they invested in the business.

question: My team is not numerically focused. Is there a way to explain RCE to my team in words, not numbers?
answer:
There are a variety of different ways RCE can be explained in words. We have included a number of these below for you to use in discussions with your team depending on the audience: 
- You don’t need to know how to calculate RCE to improve RCE. Acting like an owner and RCE are two sides of the same coin. If you act as a One Company_A owner, RCE will be improved and value will be created, and if you purposefully increase RCE you will be acting like an owner. 
- RCE tells you whether the value of your outputs exceed the value of your inputs and compares that value creation to what you could have generated had you invested in another alternative.
- RCE can explained through a simple laundromat example. Let’s say that over the last 10 years you’ve been invested in the stock market, and the company you have chosen to invest in is a publicly traded laundromat company. You’ve done pretty well with this investment; you’ve earned a return of 8.5% every year.  Sadly, you recently received an inheritance of $1,000 from a distant relative. Because you have studied the laundromat industry and understand the business inside and out, and developed a passion for it, you decide to open your own laundromat with the $1,000 inheritance by investing into the assets needed to start your business (a washer and a dryer). To create value, you must be able to earn a return better than your next best alternative – which in this case, is investing in the public laundromat company with a return of 8.5% or $85 based on your $1,000 investment. Economically speaking, this $85 is the minimum amount of money you would expect to generate to justify starting this new business instead of investing in the public company. It turns out that you were able to generate $311 of “profit” so your RCE is the difference between what you generated in “profit” ($311) versus what “profit” you could have generated in the publicly traded laundromat business ($85). As a result, you generated $226 of RCE ($311 - $85). This is how an owner thinks. If an owner has to provide capital to run a business, that owner expects a return – and the same is true for Company_A and its investors!

question: RCE sounds great but are there other companies using it?
answer:
In large part, measures like RCE stay uncommon because compensation metrics are often based on competitive pay practices that don’t encourage an ownership mindset. Strategy 101 suggests that any sustainable competitive advantage comes from possessing resources and processes, both tangible and intangible that are difficult to replicate. When realized, a RCE transformation impacts all facets of a business, where long-term value creation becomes the driving force of the organization, touching almost every aspect of business in a beneficial and profound way, that to replicate it or imitate it is very difficult. This provides a competitive advantage that will help a company dominate their respective industry.
A simple search of proxy statements for the terms “economic value added” or as it’s more commonly known, “economic profit,” yields 1,502 companies. In some cases a company will simply list “economic value added” and “economic profit” as a possible performance goal alongside other measures of performance. And although companies may have not fully adopted this measure for incentive compensation purposes, it does suggest that many companies recognize the measure as a viable metric for evaluating and rewarding executive performance.” (Source: CFO.com)
The spectrum of adopters ranges from companies with a back-office analyst that calculates it once a year as a footnote to some obscure analysis that is never seen, to those companies that are compensated on it, trained on it, use it in their daily operating decisions and make it part of the discussion in every high-level executive meeting. One great example is Ball Corporation, that has used an RCE-like measure for approximately 30 years. Varian Medical System implemented their version of RCE to much success (before their well-received recent acquisition), where they almost doubled the value of their business within 3 years.

question: What does a positive versus negative RCE mean? If RCE is negative do we necessarily shut down a project or sell a business?
answer: RCE represents past performance; negative historical RCE simply means shareholder value was destroyed in the past so if we were making decisions over, we would likely make different choices. However, this does not really matter moving forward because what is most important is the change in RCE. The difference between the RCE of this year and last year represents the sum of all the positive and negative RCE decisions made during the year. A change from negative RCE to less-negative RCE is as important as a change from positive RCE to more-positive RCE of the same magnitude.

question: Is RCE just another measure that is going to be added to our existing KPIs?
answer: No - RCE will become the one metric to drive decision-making across the organization and link value creation with compensation. Companies with too many metrics get pulled in too many directions; attempting to optimize multiple metrics means they’re likely not optimizing any single metric. A core strength of RCE is its ability to help managers balance among traditional metrics such as revenue growth, margins, and capital productivity. RCE correlates more strongly with TSR than any traditional metric and works much better as a period measure, especially below the C-Suite and executive team levels.

question: Do our old metrics still matter when we switch to RCE?
answer: Absolutely. Our previous metrics (revenue growth and EBITDA margin) are important drivers of RCE and as a result, they do remain important in an RCE framework. For example, revenue growth and EBITDA margin are drivers of Gross Cash Earnings (the profit metric component of RCE).

question: How do we reconcile RCE with our external commitments to investors?
answer: Improvement in RCE is consistent with commitments we’ve made to the Street; in fact, EBITDA margin is one of the key drivers of RCE. An RCE framework will likely make it easier to achieve the 31% EBITDA margin by 2024 that we’ve committed to publicly. Eventually, with RCE as the common language we use throughout the company, including in compensation, it will be easier to manage externally.

question: What will the RCE target be for the following year? How do I get paid a 1x bonus?
answer: Effectively, last year’s RCE will be this year’s target. So if One Company_A generates the same RCE as last year, you will receive a 1x bonus. If One Company_A generates more than last year’s RCE, you will be paid more than 1x bonus. If One Company_A generates less than last year’s RCE, you will be paid less then 1x bonus. To generate last year’s RCE, One Company_A needs to generate a required return of 8.5% on the incremental investment made during the course of the year. Zero improvement simply means that Company_A generated exactly the amount of return that was required by investors for the additional investment made in the business. By focusing on improving from last year, there is no need to arbitrarily negotiate plans. Plans will be important for planning for “greatness” but will not be used to set your target bonus.

question: Will I have less control over my pay and/or less upside potential with RCE-based compensation?
answer: The upside and downside risk will be exactly the same. Each dollar of RCE Improvement has the same value whether you achieve a bonus multiple higher than 1x or lower than 1x. The payout curve is a straight line. When RCE is linked to compensation, everyone has the ability to control their pay by acting like an owner: 1) making operating decisions that drive more growth and EBITDA through integration and operating excellence; 2) investing in innovation and operating opportunities that will meaningfully beat the required return; and 3) harvesting all activities where value cannot be created and where the resources can do more good elsewhere.

question: Will RCE discourage large investments that don’t immediately earn the cost of capital, but will create value in the long-term? What about investments driven by things like environmental or safety regulations?
answer: No. When RCE is implemented properly, it encourages profitable long-term investments that create shareholder value. Further, the RCE way of the thinking requires managers to consider risks when evaluating environmental and safety-related investments. This is what we scientifically call a “no brainer.” If regulations are not met, then RCE will be much more negative when the regulators come knocking.

question: How do I manage to plan and RCE concurrently?
answer: In an RCE framework, it is important for plans to be realistic but also challenging. RCE should remove gaming around plans, allowing for business units, teams, and employees to set stretch goals and continuously strive for improvement versus striving to simply set low expectations and beat plan.

question: Under an RCE framework, will scorecards and essential wins still be important?
answer: Eventually, scorecards and essential wins will encompass RCE metrics so they will be in alignment; however, that will likely take some time to evolve.

question: Is RCE the same as EVA? Why do we need RCE if we already use NPV?
answer:
No. While they are both economic profit measures, RCE addresses several deficiencies of EVA. First, EVA is substantially more complex than RCE and requires many more adjustments (often more than 150!). RCE’s few economic adjustments require inputs that can be drawn directly from Company_A’s income statement and balance sheet. Further, EVA can discourage growth investments by making new investments look prohibitively expensive while making older investments look comparatively “cheap” – causing businesses to sweat their prior investments. RCE has been specifically designed to address these EVA flaws in mind, so that it is much more practical to implement, tracks to TSR (Total Share Holder returns which is the price appreciation and dividends of a company) much better and is more effective as an annual performance metric. RCE is simple, provides a common language, and links value creation, behavior, and incentives. 
RCE and NPV are very consistent economically, with the main difference being that RCE works much better as an annual performance measure. Anyone familiar with the use of NPV will likely find it easy to adapt to the RCE framework.

question: What's happening to our bonus plan?
answer:
Company_A is moving from incentive compensation based on revenue, EBITDA, and Innovation to a plan based on improvement in RCE. 
Under this type of incentive structure, there is no target-setting – our goal is simple: to improve RCE.  
If we match last year’s RCE, we’ll receive a 1.0x bonus. If we improve on last year’s RCE, we’ve created value and we’ll receive greater than a 1.0x bonus.  If our RCE is lower than last year, we’ve destroyed value and will receive less than a 1.0x bonus.

question: What and why are we doing this?
answer: This change is being made to create a simple, comprehensive bonus measure that promotes an improved ownership mentality. The new metric allows for improved collaboration (due to a single metric able to be used across departments), better longer-term thinking (all years are linked together), and improved stewardship behavior over Company_A’s balance sheet resources (rather than just being focused on the Income Statement, as our current bonus is)

question: What is the intention of this change, how does it fit into the overall Company_A comp philosophy? How is this change beneficial to employees?
answer: RCE maps directly to One Company_A’s ownership culture at all levels of the company by making what’s good for the company and shareholders also good for employees and their families. Importantly, we are moving away from a bonus payout based on performance against a negotiated plan, and moving to RCE, where you can be assured that if you make a decision to improve RCE, your bonus will go up. Traditionally our business plan, which represented a 1.0 ECB payout, always included subjective growth on Sales and EBITDA targets. With the RCE plan, employees achieve a 1.0 simply by attaining the same RCE as the prior year, making it likely to lead to higher payouts for employees.

question: We already has plenty of metrics; why do they need another one?
answer: Companies with too many metrics get pulled in too many directions; attempting to optimize multiple metrics means they’re likely not optimizing any single metric. We often find that each BU/function/geography unilaterally decides which metric(s) they’ll try to optimize. A core strength of RCE is its ability to help managers balance among traditional metrics such as revenue growth, margins, and capital productivity. RCE correlates more strongly with TSR than any traditional metric and works much better as a period measure, especially below the C-Suite and executive team levels.

question: If this is so great, why haven’t I heard of it before?
answer: Fortuna is a young boutique and has not focused on its growth ambitions – until recently. Because of the sensitive and strategic nature of executive measurement, most companies prefer to limit disclosure. Varian Medical Systems has publicly disclosed its adoption of our framework in SEC filings and articles, and we’ve provided details on their implementation in our case study.

question: How is this different than EVA, which some companies tried years ago, then abandoned?
answer: Although EVA has advantages over other metrics, it has several deficiencies that RCE addresses as described earlier – particularly that it discourages long-term investments. Many early EVA implementations tended to be overly academic and complex, in most cases requiring more than 150 adjustments. RCE has been specifically designed with these EVA flaws in mind, so that it is much more practical to implement.

question: RCE sounds too complicated! How will non-finance/accounting people ever understand this?
answer: We have extensive experience in successfully enabling non-financial people to understand how they can thrive with our methodology.  Our goal is to drive value creation, not to create academic research.

question: How will the next big acquisition impact this new measure?
answer: Like organic investments (say, investment in PP&E), acquisitions are made with the intention to create positive RCE on PV basis. While large capital charge may get added in the year of acquisition, additional GCE benefit should more than offset this charge in the years following the acquisition. Some acquisitions may take longer to pay off than others, but under the RCE improvement-based incentive system target is always set to previous year actual RCE, thus making sure all positive NPV investment proportionally reward employees over the life of the investment.

question: Who decides the capital charge? For some shareholders this will be higher than we would decide ourselves.
answer: Capital charge (and required return) is determined by the riskiness of the asset, and not necessarily by the risk appetite of investors in the asset. It is meant to be prospective, and is the opportunity cost of investing in an asset, given the risk it carries. For Company_A required return is determined as 8.5%.
